definitions.definition: to provide something good to balance or reduce the bad effects of damage, loss, etc.

examples.text: Nothing can compensate for the loss of a loved one.
His voice doesn't have much range but he compensates with clever lyrics.
The advantages of the plan more than compensate for the risks associated with it.
State-of-the-art appliances may be expensive, but to compensate they will be more energy-efficient and last longer.

definitions.definition: to act in order to balance or correct something wrong or not normal

examples.text: In the second experiment, the temperature was raised to compensate for this bias.

definitions.definition: to pay somebody money because they have suffered some damage, loss, injury, etc.

examples.text: Her lawyers say she should be compensated for the suffering she had been caused.
The rail company offered to compensate passengers for any inconvenience caused.
a fund to compensate victims of abuse
The company will compensate you for the losses you have suffered.
People whose health has suffered will be compensated in full.
I expect to be compensated financially.

wordOrigin: mid 17th cent. (in the sense ‘counterbalance’): from Latin compensat- ‘weighed against’, from the verb compensare, from com- ‘together’ + pensare (frequentative of pendere ‘weigh’).
